title: Is a non-Mormon able to drink coffee in the home on a regular basis when married to a Mormon, without it affecting their ability to get a temple recommendation? - Quora

response.answer_text: I had relatives who were non-Mormon. When I say had, that means they have since passed away. As was previously mentioned in another answer, non-Mormons cannot get a temple recommend nor attend the temple. That being said, my relatives (in-laws), were still important and loved members of our family. These family members smoked, drank coffee daily, and socially drank. Just because you have family members who are non-Mormon-it does not affect your worthiness in the church, or your ability to keep the commandments- including the Word of Wisdom. This is true even if they smoke or drink around you, or store it in your home. Your church membership and worthiness solely rests on you, and you alone.

No, it doesn’t affect the Mormon spouse’s temple worthiness at all. The temple recommend question concerning this says only, “Do you keep the Word of Wisdom?” My best friend’s mother is Mormon, but her father is a non-member, and my friend grew up with a coffee maker on the counter and beers in the fridge. It’s not ideal, but it has no effect on the Mormon spouse’s temple worthiness. Not being temple worthy is not contagious. We have a colloquialism (not sure how widespread it is) that says “don’t look beyond the mark,” i.e., don’t make up commandments and rules that God never intended. This might be an example of such a time.
